 Florida, New Mexico, Arizona, Nevada, Colorado
 
 You cannot possibly win those states without winning the Hispanic vote, and in ALL of those states democrats are leading republicans by double digits in the Hispanic population. The democrats could run a monkey against about any republican in those states and still win. The tragic thing is that it is not the GOP candidates themselves that have sunk them with the Hispanic voters, it is the GOP base that has done it.

When you see polls where they cite "white males" what they are doing is using them as a control groups because they have the broadest range of political views out there. 
 
 Bill Clinton won the presidency because he won the womans vote...especially lower and middle class women. I think that we can pretty much count on Hillary doing the same. When the republicans were worried about Hillary running last time (2001) the republicans talked to Sibelius (Ks Governor) about switching parties and running in the VP slot in an attempt to nullify Hillary's advantage with women voters.
 
 Hillary scores extremely high on economic issues, immigration, health care and education. She scores about even with republican candidates when it comes to security and scores much lower when it comes to military matters.
 
 Ultimately, it probably does not matter who the Democrats end up running. The republicans are going to loose. That is why the republican candidates are such a joke this time around. Nobody good wants to run because they don't want to waste a shot at the presidency on an election that they already know they will loose.

They have lost the fiscal conservatives, they have lost the libertarians, they have lost the minorities that once supported them (most notably the cubans in florida). 
 
 I also think you are attaching FAR too much importance to the strategic intentions of your average voters. Voters in primaries vote for who they like. They do not look into the distant future and strategize about who they think can win agains the other party because they assume that whoever they like the most, others will like the most. That strategy has been tried before ("voe for me because even though the other guy can beat me, they can't win the general election") and it has failed MISERABLY. 
 
 Look at the polls. Hillary is WAY out front. In the general election polls her closest conteder is Guiliani, and she is way out in front of him on most.
 
 http://www.pollingreport.com/2008.htm is a good place to go if you want to see several different polls in one place. 
 
 Personally, I think that hillary will be a terrible president BUT I think we need to resign ourselves to the fact that unless something serious changes, she will be the next president. Look at some of the "party only" polls (where they don't ask about a particular canidate, they jsut ask which party the person is most likely to vote for). The democrats are beating the republcans by over TEN points. That is HUGE, especially since those "party only" polls have proven to be the most accurate predictor of election results...far more accurate than polls that actually use names. 
 
 This is one reason I am really hoping for a Ron Paul upset. If we ran Ron Paul, not only could we get the libertarians and social conservatives back that we lost, but Paul actually plays very well with democrats for whom fiscal responsibility and freedom are priorities as well.
